Title: Aortic Regurgitation
Description: Sound is that of a normal S1 followed by a sharp or slapping S2 and a blowing, high-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Aortic Stenosis Murmur
Description: The 6th beat is a ventricular premature beat (VPB). The 7th beat illustrates post-VPB potentiation of the murmur due to increased left ventricular filling during the post-VPB compensatory pause.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Aortic Stenosis Murmur (Crescendo-Decrescendo Ejection Murmur)
Description: Sound is that of a crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur. The 6th beat in the sample is a ventricular premature beat (VPB). The 7th beat illustrates post-VPB potentiation of the murmur due to increased left ventricular filling during the post-VPB compensatory pause, which causes increased turbulent flow past the stenotic valve during the next ventricular contraction.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Austin Flint Murmur
Description: S1 is soft; S2 is obscured by a soft regurgitant murmur and a louder, low-pitched, late-diastolic murmur. The diastolic murmur mimics mitral stenosis and is attributed to mitral valve leaflet vibration or mild obstruction caused by rapid regurgitant flow.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Crackles
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Crackles
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Crackles
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Diastolic Knock
Description: A diastolic knock is a loud S3 caused by constrictive pericarditis.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: E to A Change
Description: Areas of consolidation cause a patient's vocalized "E" to sound like "A."
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Fourth Heart Sound
Description: Sound is that of S4–S1–S2.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Friction Rub
Description: A leathery sound that fluctuates with the respiratory cycle.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Mitral Regurgitation Murmur
Description: This holosystolic mitral regurgitation murmur maintains the same intensity throughout systole and extends from S1 to S2.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Mitral Regurgitation Murmur With 3rd Heart Sound
Description: An S3 that accompanies mitral regurgitation suggests a dilated left ventricle and progression to heart failure.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Mitral Regurgitation Murmur With 3rd Heart Sound

Title: Mitral Stenosis
Description: Sample illustrates typical features of mitral stenosis: The murmur is rumbling or low-pitched and begins early in diastole with crescendo to S2.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Mitral Stenosis in Atrial Fibrillation
Description: Intensity of the murmur of mitral stenosis varies with changes in length of the cardiac cycles. In this sample of atrial fibrillation, the murmur increases in intensity with longer cycles and decreases in intensity with shorter cycles, because the volume of blood flowing across the mitral valve changes. Overall intensity is decreased because atrial contraction is lost.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Mitral Stenosis Murmur
Description: Prominent mitral stenosis murmur with presystolic accentuation, described as resembling a growl and bark. Mitral stenosis murmurs are typically rumbling and low-pitched and crescendo through diastole.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Mitral Valve Opening Snap
Description: Sound is that of S1–A2–OS with a relatively long A2–OS interval. The opening snap (OS), most commonly caused by mitral stenosis, is thought to be caused by abrupt downward bulging (snapping) of the anterior leaflet as left ventricular pressure drops below left atrial pressure during diastole. A2–OS can be distinguished from a split S2 by dynamic maneuvers (OS intensity increases with inspiration, A2–OS interval widens with standing), a triple S2 (ie, A2–P2–OS), and a louder volume at the apex.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Mitral Valve Prolapse
Description: The systolic murmur in this sample has a honking or whooping character, which is attributed to valvular leaflet vibration.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Mitral Valve Prolapse (With Late-Systolic Click)
Description: Sound is that of S1 followed by a late-systolic click and S2.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Normal Breath Sounds
Description: Typical breath sounds heard over most lung fields.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Normal Bronchial Breath Sounds
Description: Typical breath sounds heard over the trachea and areas of lung consolidation.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Patent Ductus Arteriosus Murmurs
Description: The murmur of patent ductus arteriosus is classically continuous and machine-like in character. It may be accompanied by an S3 and a mitral diastolic flow murmur when left-sided volumes are large.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Patent Ductus Arteriosus Murmurs
Description: The murmur of patent ductus arteriosus is classically continuous and machine-like in character. It may be accompanied by an S3 and a mitral diastolic flow murmur when left-sided volumes are large.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Pericardial Friction Rub
Description: Friction rubs are frequently described as creaking or scratching but may sound like more common murmurs. This rub is triphasic, with a soft systolic component and 2 louder components in quick succession during early diastole.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Pericardial Friction Rub
Description: Friction rubs are frequently described as creaking or scratching but may sound like more common murmurs. This rub is triphasic, with a soft systolic component and 2 louder components in quick succession during early diastole.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Pulmonary Ejection Click
Description: High pulmonary artery pressures may dilate the pulmonary artery, stretching the valve ring and causing a click when taut cusps open rapidly.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Pulmonic Stenosis Murmur
Description: The murmur becomes audible only with inspiration (“in”) because inspiration decreases intrathoracic pressure, drawing more blood into the right ventricle and increasing right ventricular outflow.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Split First Heart Sound
Description: S1 splitting is normal in many patients and is thought to be caused by mitral valve closure followed by an aortic ejection sound.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Split Second Heart Sound
Description: Sound is that of S1–S2 at rest (“out”) and S1–A2–P2 with inspiration (“in”). S2 splits with inspiration because intrathoracic pressure decreases, drawing more blood into the right ventricle and postponing pulmonic valve closure.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Split Second Heart Sound in Left Bundle Branch Block
Description: Sound is that of paradoxical splitting, ie, S1–P2–A2 at rest (“out”) and S1–S2 with inspiration (“in”). Left bundle branch block delays aortic valve closure, so that split is audible at rest; inspiration decreases intrathoracic pressure, drawing more blood into the right ventricle and postponing pulmonic valve closure until it is superimposed on A2 and splitting becomes inaudible.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Split Second Heart Sound in Left Bundle Branch Block

Title: Split Second Heart Sound in Right Bundle Branch Block
Description: Sound is that of wide splitting, ie, S1–A2–P2 at rest (“out”) with an even wider A2–P2 interval with inspiration (“in”). Right bundle branch block delays pulmonic valve closure so that S2 splitting becomes audible at rest. Inspiration decreases intrathoracic pressure, drawing more blood into the right ventricle and postponing pulmonic valve closure even more, so that the normal split becomes wider.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Split Second Heart Sound in Right Bundle Branch Block

Title: Split Second Heart Sound With Atrial Septal Defect
Description: Sound is that of fixed second heart sound (S2) splitting, ie, S1–A2–P2 at rest (“out”) and with inspiration (“in”). Splitting is fixed because the volume of flow through the right ventricle is increased throughout the respiratory cycle, eliminating the normal delay in closure of the pulmonic valve associated with inspiration.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Split Second Heart Sound With Atrial Septal Defect
Split Second Heart Sound With Atrial Septal Defect

Title: Split Second Heart Sound With Atrial Septal Defect
Description: Sound is that of fixed second heart sound (S2) splitting, ie, S1–A2–P2 at rest (“out”) and with inspiration (“in”). Splitting is fixed because the volume of flow through the right ventricle is increased throughout the respiratory cycle, eliminating the normal delay in closure of the pulmonic valve associated with inspiration.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Split Second Heart Sound With Atrial Septal Defect
Split Second Heart Sound With Atrial Septal Defect

Title: Stridor
Description: Inspiratory stridor in croup.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Stridor
Description: Inspiratory stridor in croup.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Summation Gallop
Description: Sound is that of S4–S1–S2–S3 in rapid succession.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Third Heart Sound
Description: Sound is that of S1–S2–S3.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Ventricular Septal Defect Murmur
Description: The murmur of a ventricular septal defect is similar to that of mitral regurgitation but is louder at the left lower sternal border than at the apex.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Ventricular Septal Defect Murmur
Description: The murmur of a ventricular septal defect is similar to that of mitral regurgitation but is louder at the left lower sternal border than at the apex.
Copyright: Recording provided by Jules Constant, MD.

Title: Wheezing
Description: Prolonged expiratory phase with wheezing.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Wheezing
Description: Prolonged expiratory phase with wheezing.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

Title: Wheezing
Description: Prolonged expiratory phase with wheezing.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of David W. Cugell, MD.

TopicLocations.TopicName: Wheezing and Asthma in Infants and Young Children

Title: Whooping Cough (Adult Patient)
Description: Pertussis in an adult, with whooping. In this recording, the patient coughs without inspiration until he has emptied his lungs of air, then breathes in with a whoop. The whoop is caused by vocal cord adduction during inspiration.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of Doug Jenkinson, MD.

Title: Whooping Cough (Classic Whoop)
Description: Pertussis in a child, with whooping. Pertussis causes paroxysmal coughing; only about half of patients develop classic whooping. In this recording, the child coughs without inspiration until she has emptied her lungs of air, then breathes in with a whoop. The whoop is caused by vocal cord adduction during inspiration.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of Doug Jenkinson, MD.

Title: Whooping Cough (Paroxysm)
Description: Pertussis in a child, without whooping. Pertussis causes paroxysmal coughing; only about half of patients develop classic whooping. In this recording, the child coughs without inspiration until she has emptied her lungs of air, then breathes in. There is a slight pause between the paroxysm and inspiration. In severe cases of pertussis, this pause may be long enough to qualify as apnea; children may become cyanotic, and the apnea may be life threatening.
Copyright: Audio file courtesy of Doug Jenkinson, MD.
